title: Lycium shawii
text:
Lycium shawii, desert thorn or Arabian boxthorn is a <a href="species">species</a> of <a href="thorn%20%28plant%20material%29">thorn</a>y <a href="shrub">shrub</a> adapted to <a href="desert">desert</a> <a href="environment%20%28biophysical%29">environment</a>s, and can be found throughout the <a href="Arabian%20peninsula">Arabian peninsula</a>, and some places in <a href="Africa">Africa</a>. The thin <a href="leaf">leave</a>d, rigid bush grows up to high, with a lot of branches and alternating spines that vary in size, and grow along the branches and on their tips. The leaves narrow towards their base. It produces small whitish-pink or purple <a href="flower">flower</a>s from September until April, and <a href="red%20pea">red pea</a>-sized <a href="seed">seed</a>y <a href="berries">berries</a> that are edible. <a href="Habitat">Habitat</a>s include <a href="gravel">gravel</a> plains and <a href="foothills">foothills</a> up to , as well as <a href="wadi">wadi</a>s. <a href="Plant">Plant</a>s often growing nearby include "<a href="Acacia%20tortilis">Acacia tortilis</a>" and "<a href="Prosopis%20cineraria">Prosopis cineraria</a>".
Uses.
The stems, leaves and berries are used in traditional medicine. In <a href="Yemen">Yemen</a>, the pounded leaves of this shrub have been used as a <a href="cure">cure</a> for <a href="eye">eye</a> <a href="ailment">ailment</a>s. The berries have a laxative effect and were used in traditional medicine to relieve constipation and as a diuretic. Livestock eat new growth on the plant.
